reviewText: No, "Child's Play 3" isn't a magnificent film by any stretch of the imagination. So why do I think it is worth watching? It is purely entertaining. It has plenty of gore and plenty of those classic Chucky one-liners. The military setting also benefited the movie, giving it a different feel than the others and making it all much more fresh (I especially appreciated the paintball gag). I have been wanting this movie to be released on DVD for the longest time, and finally, Universal has answered my wishes -- that's the only logical explanation I can come up with, because I know there wasn't a swarm of fans lobbying for this release -- it's the most hated in the series! But I love it. If I felt guilty about loving it, then I guess I would call it a guilty pleasure. But I digress. "Child's Play 3" finds our poor, tortured little Andy growing up. He's stopped playing with dolls, but at age 16, he seems to have caused enough trouble to land him in military school (can't see what he did wrong -- although judging by Justin Whalin's performance, all those foster homes didn't appreciate the whining or the moping). However, Chucky has been absurdly resurrected and follows Andy, only to realize that there is new blood to be spilled. Overall, I don't see anything bad about this movie. It's the third in a horror franchise that was low-budget to begin with. The Chucky doll looks better and moves much more fluidly than in the first two. The peripheral characters may be insignificant, but are colorful and either easy to love or easy to hate (always a good asset for a horror movie.). Fans of Chucky & this series will surely find something they like in this, all others are advised to just stay away. The DVD is somewhat disappointing, saved by the novelty of the movie being available on DVD for the the first time. All we are treated to is a theatrical trailer. However, if you are a fan of the movie, it is worth buying the DVD because is isn't very expensive in the first place and the picture & sound quality makes the purchase worth it.
summary: Chucky makes his way to boot camp...and DVD!

reviewText: Unless you're into military and stuff like that, I find this film really disappoints. There are a few aspects of the series that are good, which I will explain later. First, let me say that Andy Barclay is not a child in this movie. Rather, he is 16, and not played by the same actor that portrayed him in Child's Play and Child's Play 2. Child's Play 2 is the last movie in the series in which Chucky was after a "kid", and this is the last movie he's after anybody in particular. In the next two films in the series, Chucky and his bride kill people for the pleasure, and not for any particular reason at all.That all being said, Child's Play 3 is still an all right movie. There is more comedy in this movie than there was in the previous two films, but this film is still all right. I was able to sit through this one from start to finish in one sitting.I can really sense greed as a main topic in this movie. It's because the creator of the "Good Guys" dolls believes the bad hype died down, because it's been 10 years since the Good Guy doll terrorized Andy, and he decides to re-release the Good Guys dolls to make more money. I sense that he is really money greedy, and from his greed, his decision actually puts Andy and his friends at the army camp in danger.It's the last Chucky movie that had humor in it without going overboard. For example, Chucky finds a box of Playboy magazines underneath Andy's bed and turns to him and says "Andy, how you've grown!"Chucky's back for a third round of blood, one that may disappoint some Child's Play fans that are expecting to see a movie where Andy is just a little bit older (like a month or so older) and once again have the poor child terrorized by the evil Chucky doll, so in that way it may disappoint. But, they still kept the Andy Barclay character (for one more movie, anyway...) and they resurrected Chucky (which, it never made sense to me why they can resurrect them so many times, but if a dog dies, like in Marley and Me, they can't resurrect them in the sequel. Or perhaps Titanic, that they couldn't make a sequel and resurrect Jack, even if he became a Dream Demon, like Freddy Krueger).If you read this review, thanks for reading my rambling on and on about the movie. I hope my review can help you make an informed decision to purchase this movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What's it about?Chucky's back...again!, re-animated by the Play Pal toy company who decide after 8 years that it's time to put `Good Guy' dolls back in production; deja vu anyone? After locating Andy Barclay's whereabouts (haven't i said this already?) Chucky finds him grown up and in Military School. When Chucky realizes new plastic body means new human body (huh?), he sets his sights on young impressionable kid Tyler, now Andy must save himself and Tyler's soul.Is it any good?Writer Don Mancini gives us plenty of Chucky one-liners, more violence and comedy but absolutely zero horror, Child's Play 3 is about as scary as a quadriplegic assassin. The Military School location gives off a different feeling than the previous two but the plot just feels rushed and pointless. Whalin and Reeves give pretty good performances bouncing off each other well, as for the Tyler character; i kind of wanted him to die, sounds bad i know but he's just so irritating. Anyway Child's Play 3 will still appeal to Chucky fans, he is more ruthless than ever, so if you just wan't to watch creative gore-fest kills and clever puppetry then this movie is for you.Best bit?"That haircut ain't regulation soldier". Maj. Botnick played by Andrew Robinson tries to give Chucky a haircut but ends up on the business end of a cutthroat razor.Did you know?The first film in the series where Chucky uses a gun as a weapon.

Director, made a clever sequel, although, it has the same story but the filmmakers manages to make it different as possible. Don Mancini, who wrote, the first two has some funny lines and situations that Highlight this One. Which is much better and entertaining than the first two. But it didn't do well at the Box Office as the Another two movies. It's a fast moving, likable sequel, which most people though, it was the last Chucky flick. Grade:B+.

reviewText: Another sequel, I feared for the producers and writers. The first and second were in their own class but was it really worth their while to risk creating another sequel after the way Chucky was killed off in Part 2? As  well as this, the film was released a year after the second which sounded  to me like this was just written in a day or two. The horror and suspense  have disapeared in this movie, comedy and humor take the leading themes.  Andy has now grown up, played by Justin Whalin who never really did much  for me here or as Jimmy in the Superman series. In military camp to  hopefully forget about everything life can be normal again. But Chucky  returns once again to do harm. The plot is totally unbelievable here-  Chucky's blood enters that of another goodguy doll now in production. How  incredible can that be? Brad Dourif is back as the bad doll who does in  fairness provide some decent humour. But that's all that keeps the  disapointed fans watching really. Andy must finish the fight once and for  all and protect young Tyler from being Chucky's next victim. Routine,worn  out horror saga which was just made to squeeze more money out of the  creased series.

reviewText: Chucky has always been my favorite bogeyman since I was a kid. HE WAS SCARY! I remember the days when Chucky bankrupted the doll "My Buddy", cute doll but very similar to him. Every kid back then was scared at that doll because of Chucky. =SNow! This third sequel is pretty weak in comparison to the first two movies. It's still a slasher/horror film but less scary and more stupid. (SPOILERS!) I mean... Chucky revived because some of his blood felt on melted plastic? The movie is set on 1996? If Andy is no longer Chucky's target then why would Chucky bother to warn him about that? Isn't something wrong with the grenade explosion scene? Also, one of the reasons that I didn't like this movie is because the environment is not scary, I really don't think that a place like a military school is suitable for a Chucky movie.I think that Seed of Chucky is the worst, Child's Play 3 was pretty bad, Bride of Chucky was so so (stupid comedy but interesting concept), Curse of Chucky was good, Child's Play 2 was great, and Child's Play is the best. I hope that the Chucky series will go on like Curse of Chucky, more horror and less stupidity.Adios.
summary: Not bad as Seed of Chucky but not good as the first two movies.

reviewText: In "Child's Play 3", Andy is older now and at a millitary school.  However, a young African American boy is now Chucky's new apparent target.  This movie is another boring sequel in the already very tired series involving the killer "good guy" doll, but I did find the mock war scene amusing when Chucky substituted live rounds for the blanks they were supposed to be shooting...unfortunately, that's the highlight of this movie.  This movie is again dominated by the recurring theme of Chucky trying to find a young boy so that he can live again in a human body...the acting is poor and the movie is boring.  Unless you are a diehard Chucky fan, avoid this one along with the rest of the series which gets significantly and progressively worse from this one forward, unless you enjoy watching silly and downright stupid movies, not that I am saying anything is wrong with that. :)
summary: No better and no worse than part 2...just boring and stupid.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Set 8 years after Child's Play 2, this sequel sees Andy Barclay attending Military School and getting bullied by the Drill Sergeant. Meanwhile, the Play Pals company has reopened the Good Guy factory and is starting production of the doll once more. But when clearing away Chucky's grisly remains, some of his blood spills into a vat of molten plastic and he is born once more in a new body.After a good old strangulation to get the circulation going he locates Andy at his military school and somehow figures out a way to mail himself there. However, once the package gets there it is promptly snatched by a very annoying, extremely gay and highly wimpy little kid called Tyler. Since he has a new body Chucky reveals his birth name once more, hoping to get a fast and easy ticket out of his plastic shell. As before there are too many distractions.And as before the film spends way too much time with boring humans who spend too much time lurking in the dark wondering why a doll seems to appear and reappear and not enough time with Chucky. He IS the star of the show and he should OWN this movie. The director never really gives him the chance. Which is a shame since the animatronics had improved over Child's Play 2 and Chucky is beginning to look nastily cute. And more and more like Brad Dourif if you look hard enough.The score is a major downer though. Greame Revell's wonderful orchestral adventure of Child's Play 2 has been replaced with a horrid synthesized, death-metal score filled with tacky and unimaginative stingers. Revell, fortunately, returned for Bride of Chucky.Jack Bender's direction (he's done episodes of Lost, Alias and The Sopranos) is slick but lacks edge, invention or humor. He seems to be ignorant of the potential Chucky has and treats the film like another mechanical TV series with no spark or signature.Child's Play 3 is no more than a competent sequel. Writer Don Mancini said he wasn't even ready to do a 3rd movie but Universal forced him to before the second was even released. As he was out of ideas he claims this film to be his least favorite of them all. If a better director were involved it could still have been a good film instead of being a merely an above average (by a tiny, tiny bit) one.Filmed in standard widescreen, the DVD is in 1.85:1 anamorphic widescreen with Dolby 2.0 surround. The only extra is an R-rated red band trailer.

reviewText: Child's Play (1991). Rated "R". Running Time: One hour, 29 mins.Director: Jack Bender. Written by Don Mancini.Returning: Peter Haskell as "Sullivan". Brad Douriff as the voice of "Chucky" again.This movie is not for young children to see. It is a horror movie with violence.Chucky the doll is nothing but a glob of wax and plastic. but someone has entered the doll factory to clean it up. A sharp moving device spikes into the glob and blood comes out. It is moved across a vat of melted flesh-colored plastic as blood drips into it. The Good Guys dolls are being made again and so is Chucky. Despite the bad publicity from Andy Barclay horrifying events with Chucky eight years ago, the company is putting Good Guys dolls back on the market. Sullivan (Peter Haskell), the CEO, is presented with the first Good Guys doll off the line. It just happens to be Chucky who later kills his victim. Now with Sullivan out of the way, Chucky must find Andy (now played by Justin Whalin), who is now 16 years old and enlisted at Kent Military School.Filmed in Boonville, Missouri. Atlanta, Georgia. Los Angeles, California.Child's Play (1988).Child's Play 2 [HD] (1990).Child's Play 3 (1991).Bride of Chucky [HD] (1998).Seed of Chucky [HD] (2004).Curse of Chucky (Unrated)(2013).Update: Don Mancini says he will make a sequel to Curse of Chucky.
summary: Is third time a charm for Chucky?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Apparently, the writer of the three original Chucky films, Don Mancini, said somewhere that this one was his least favorite. The reasoning, or so it was stated -- Mancini was asked to begin writing a script for '3' before '2' was even finished filming. Therefore, Mancini was a bit milked already from exhausting what novel ideas he had for the first sequel, and they pretty much squeezed him dry for this installment.But, 'Child's Play 3' doesn't earn points for creativity... I mean, almost never. And, yes, it may be the weakest link in the original trilogy. That being said, these 'negatives' never stand out when I rewatch this film. No sir. What stands out in my mind whenever I happen to catch Chucky 3 is how much better it is than a fan of the series could have ever expected. In that, though this isn't some sort of legendary horror film, it is one that comes to the table with a sense of seriousness and intent by all the crew working behind it, and the result is something that, at least to me, is probably better than 95% of #3's in any particular series -- and if secluded merely to the horror genre, that number must jump up even more.Anyway, this is just surprisingly well done. The directing is commendable, and looking at the catalogue of Chucky 3's director now fifteen years later, it's interesting to see this one's gone on to make a few of the episodes for ABC's new hit series 'Lost'. Especially within the first half of the film, there are really a lot of spectacular scenes. The one that stood out most for me was when Andy first spots Chucky while doing drills on the field. Filmed almost entirely in slow-mo, we get to see Andy's first realization that Chucky is in fact back in his life... cut to doll being carried around with dead smile... cut to Andy losing his composure, baffling his gun amidst a trembling facial expression. OK fine -- it's not The Godfather -- but the point is I really believe these guys had done some studying, and were not just lazy film-school amateur's with a bucket of cash to pump out a sequel (which, given this one was created within such a short timespan of '2', would have seemed even more likey).I won't zoom closer on any of the other formidable filmmaking elements in Chucky 3, except for the thing that, for my money, holds the film together despite other fine efforts. Like the kid who played Andy Barclay in the first two films, Justin Whalin (who plays a teenage Andy) is adept and believable -- again -- 'especially' given his age and the fact that this is a sequel to a horror film with a director who probably didn't have a lot of actor-influence. I'm now far beyond the reaching age of the film's intended audience (I.E. the bright children of Earth who:  1. Haven't learnt to dissociate themselves -- yet -- from their scariest imaginations and 2. Through whatever means have viewing  access to a rated R psychotic doll movie). Point is this -- I saw  all three of the Child's Play films when I was around 10, and each subsequent one (though out of order) seemed to throw more emotional trauma on top of the last. Sure, it was painful at the time, but had any of the three opted for a less than largely credible actor at the forefront, I don't think the overall impact would have been nearly the same.OK so we get a lot of blood yet again, though truth be told the deaths aren't quite as memorable or clever as we've seen before. One in particular, involving a dump truck, is just downright sadistic (though it is Chucky, I regress....). An interesting element of comparison is also Chucky himself and how he looks and acts. For whatever reason, it has changed a little bit. Overall Chucky's face feels wider, more polished, and by the end of the film, wider and polished with big freaking Bugs Bunny teeth sticking out of his gawking mouth. It's a different look that is at times subtle and at times not, but it's been too long since I've seen the prior two films to really compare. Must say though there were definitely moments where I caught myself thinking "that don't look right." Narrative wise the story doesn't offer anything much (and the last fifteen minutes is pretty idiotic actually), but I did like the military school setting. If nothing else, it's a relatively distinct environment for a bunch of young kids and I am not terribly knowledgable on the subject, so by default I was interested in the location of the film. Naturally, I think it was also a good choice because it evaded the tendency for Chucky to go wild again amongst the (sub)urban areas.Bottom line is that like many others I do tend to place this one at the bottom of the list within the trilogy, but for what it's worth I don't think any of them are head and shoulders above each other. They've all got their distinct style and tone and in my opinion we were lucky to have two sequels that showed passion and integrity on the filmmakers part's. Generally I think of myself as a fan of good film, and I don't doubt that most people would laugh at calling these films respectable or even impassioned. But  personally, I just feel that way -- the people making these few little absurdist horror flicks really might have had some sort of collective, motivating energy from the projects and exerted that much more into them because of it. I mean hell, how else could this little trilogy here garnish such a cult following? I mean, you mention Chucky to most any American over 12 years old, and a killer doll pops immediately into mind. SOMETHING special happened with these films.
summary: Chucky opts for a darker skin complexion via seven year old Tyler
Title: N/A

reviewText: Nor is it scary. It takes a really horrible director and writer to destroy a blockbuster box office smash series. The second sequels are always the victims to crazy script writers and directors. (Example: Child's Play 3, Alien 3, Omen III: The Final Conflict.)In this wanna-be re-hash of the original, we expected, as much hype as it got, a non-stop, tongue in cheek, roller coaster ride. In whole, it [was bad]. I was 12 when I first saw it and I was so angry, that I (And most of the audience) walked out the theatre demanding refunds. I really don't know what ...Bender was on at the time. And the script must have been written in at least one day, because it came out not even exactly one-year after it's predecessor. There must have been so much ad-libbing it wasn't funny. The first two did very, very well in the box office, this one wasn't even on the top 50. It's a shame to see this one stain the 'Child's Play' family name. And it lacks originaility. Stupid characters, cheesy plot, non-stop laughable death scenes, and dumb acting. The movie starts out with the Play Pals factory being re-opened and a machine digging into Chucky's ribs. It's stupid to see Chucky back, since his death scene was so terrible in the last. So his blood infuses inside a new Good Guy doll (Stupid). He kills the owner of Play Pals. The rest of the movie is corny, you won't believe!16 year old Andy Barclay (Justin Whalin) is being transfered to a military school. It's stupid because it doesn't say why he is going there. The plot holes are so abundant in this film. Chucky also wants to transfer his soul into a new child, which is also dumb. It's up to Andy to save him.First mistake: Making Andy a grown up. It's ridiculous to see Mr. Whalin stumble over one-liners. The writer/director could have given the role to Alex Vincent who did an awesome job playing a traumatized Andy. Second screw up: Making Andy a hero instead of a victim. I always liked the idea of Chucky trying to take over Andy's soul. Whalin makes Andy a wuss, also. Whatever happend to the tough as nails, no nonsense Andy Barclay we've known in the first two?The military settings was also unnecessary. I wish they hired me in charge of the writing/directing. I sure would have had it somewhat like the oringinal with the Chuck still trying to get inside Andy's body. I know it sounds monotonus, but there shouldn't have even been a 'Child's Play 3'. It's not a wonder why we haven't seen these actors and actresses on any other movies besides this garbage. It's fun in own little trashy way. NOT! ...

reviewText: This movie is my least favorite of the Child's Play series. But it is entertaining and worth seeing and buying. Justin Whalin is *FANTASTIC* in this movie. I just bought the DVD (PAL format only) from eBay. The PAL format will only work with DVD players that are PAL compatible. So once I found out that my DVD player is PAL compatible I had to buy it so that I will have all of the Child's Play DVDs (I only have to get Child's Play 2 and The Bride Of Chucky). Child's Play 3 is only available on DVD in countries like the United Kingdom, Scotland and Austraila.I first got my DVD player because I couldn't find Child's Play One on VHS in any store (to buy). All I could find it on was DVD. So I got a DVD player and my first DVD was Child's Play One.If you haven't seen the Child's Play series I suggest renting the series from your local video. My favorite Child's Play movies are Child's Play 2 and The Bride Of Chucky. I can't wait until they are released next month on DVD.

reviewText: Don Mancini (creator) has stated that this entry in the Child's Play series came too soon after the release of the second entry and was demanded by the studio (it was released only nine months after the second)that he really had no fresh ideas to give to the series. And to me, it was obvious.The factory where Chucky was created is up and running ten years after the last Andy / Chucky dilemma. The Good Guy dolls are being created again, and during the creation Chucky's blood is luckily still going ten years later and is mixed into the melted plastic used to create the dolls; therefore he is reborn. Proof #153 that this film was rushed: Plot Holes. They don't stop there, but I won't continue going on with them.Casting is another obvious reason. Justin Whalin takes the place of Alex Vincent as Andy. Vincent was stated as not wanting to come back for another film so the writers / producers / whoever decided to go ten years into the future with a 16 year old Andy (just only nine months after the second is released and Andy is six years old, mind you). Aside from a few "eh" moments, Justin Whalin is the only one in the cast you remotely care for or want to see.Brad Dourif delivers Chucky's lines with total awareness, and this is where Chucky's one-liners begin to be even better. This is sort of where he be comes the anti-hero as we love him and want more from him than we do of the protagonists. And that's exactly where the fourth entry takes us.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Now I'm reviewing the underrated Childs Play 3 it's not a sequel that is well liked by fans but honestly I have always thought that this was a good sequel. I like this better than Bride & Seed Of Chucky those movies I'll get into why I don't like part 4 & why I hate part 5. I know fans hate it cause they made Andy older & gave it a Military School setting. Iike The Military School setting & for the time Don Mancini was given he did a very good job. He was under pressure by Universal to write a script for Childs Play 3 & part 2 hadn't even came out yet. Don Mancini says this is his least favorite of the franchise. Yeah Bride & Seed are something to be really proud of. Made for $13 million made $20 million it was the least grossing of the franchise. Directed by Jack Bender he's done a lot of TV work. It stars Brad Dourif doing the voice of Chucky, Justin Whalin as Andy Barclay, Perrey Reeves as Kristen DiSilva, Travis Fine as Cadet Lieutenant Shelton, Dean Jacobson as Harold Whitehurst & Jermey Sylvers as Roland Tyler. The story is The Play Pals Toy Company is going to relaunch The Good Guy Dolls after about 8 years of not making due to bad plublicity. You have these people cleaning out the factory from part 2 & some of the parts of The Chucky Doll go into some hot plastic so the 1st Good Guy Doll off the asmbley line is Chucky. They give it to the owner of the company. That night Chucky strangles tht guy he says just like the good old days. He gets on the computer finds out where Andy is at. You have Andy who is 16 yrs old he's in Military School & this kid named Tyler befriends him. I know in The TV version they introduce him earlier on a bus taking them to the academy. Then he meets a fellow cadet Whitehurst who is bullied by Shelton & his buddies. Outside they are doing some military drills Shelton is yelling at Andy he wants him to call him Lieutenant Colonel Shelton & then say Sir. Then he talks to Whitehurst like he's a pos he thinks that he's a real drill seargent. He's unlikeable but unlikeable for the right reasons. You have the introduction of a likeable character Kristen DiSilva who calls Shelton an a  s  s hole. He makes her do 25 push ups. Andy & DiSilva become fast friends she teaches him how to aim a gun properly. At The PX Tyler finds out that he hasn't got a letter from his Dad who is in The Air Force. He's given a package to give to Andy. He finds out it's a Good Guy Doll. Tyler takes it The Armory where  Chucky pops out he realizes that since he's got a new body he can just tell Tyler who he really is & transfer his soul to him. Chucky says "Great I'm going to be a bro." Before he can do that some Supior Officers find them there cause they are going to do War Games. The Colonel takes the doll outside Andy spots it The Colonel throws it in a dumpster. Then you get 1 of my favorite kills in the franchise where Chucky is in the back of this garbage truck he screams for help. The Garbage Man goes in & looks for him. Chucky gets in the truck turns on the compactor even though you don't see much The Garbage Man has kind of brutal death. Later on you have Andy in his room where Chucky attacks him & he tells him that he's going after Tyler. Andy takes a shoe that Whitehurst shined for Shelton. Andy beats the doll with it. Shelton comes in he takes the doll. Andy goes into Shelton's room to get it Chucky runs off. He's mad that the doll is gone so Shelton makes all the cadet's go outside & do exercises to impress his Supior's. Chucky is looking for Tyler you have DiSilva in The Colonel's Office she is looking for a file on Andy. DiSilva & her friend find Tyler in the closet they all hear The Colonel coming to The Office. He comes in takes the doll throws it in the trash. Chucky pops out scares The Colonel & he has a heart attack. Chucky's reaction is pretty funny. He says " You got to beph  u  c  k  in  g kidding me!  You have this Military Barber who cuts Whitehurst's hair he says presto you're bald. The Barber is played by Andrew Robinson. The Barber finds the dolls & he's going to cut it's hair Chucky takes a razor blade slits The Barber's throat & says "Presto you're dead." Chucky replaces the paintball rounds with live rounds in The Red Team's rifles. Andy needs to get to Tyler before Chucky does. DiSilva tells Andy where Shelton keeps the map at cause Tyler is on the red team. Disilva tells Andy her 1st name they kind of start up a realtionship. Shelton heads out cause Andy stole the map. Andy is looking for Tyler he is told by some kids that a man named Charles took him. Tyler runs off when Chucky pulls a knife on him. He meets up with Andy where Shelton says we got a POW he's taking it seriously like it's a real military operation. He radios to DiSivla to return she is attacked by Chucky where he radios to Shelton to bring him the boy. So they go to where Chucky is at Chucky also lured the red team there where they open fire Shelton is shot dead which made me happy. While they are all arguing & 1 of Shelton's buddies iis beating up Andy Chucky throws a grenade Whitehurst covers himself over the grenade to save his fellow cadet's. Tyler runs off where he ends up at a carnival Tyler tries to get help from this cop who happens to have the doll & he's killed. Andy & DiSilva go look for Tyler they find the cop DiSilva takes his gun. You get to the finish in this haunted house ride not as good as the toy factory in part 2 but it is a well done scene. Chucky shoots DiSilva in the leg. There's this reaper thing in the ride that cuts part of Chucky's face off Tyler runs off but he is knocked out by this prop thing. Chucky tries to do the soul transfer thing Andy shoots Chucky's arm off & then shoots him in the chest. Andy checks on Tyler. Chucky jumps on his back tries to choke Andy Tyler gives him a knife he cuts Chucky's hand off he falls into this huge fan silced up. As they take Kristen DiSilva off The Police take Andy in for questioning he tells Kristen that he's been through this before. To me this was the end of The Childs Play series if you don't like Childs Play 3 that's fine don't leave hateful comments if you leave a comment tell me why you don't like it. I liked it cause you still had characters that you cared about they felt like normal people it's straight forward like part 2 was I like The Military School setting. Jack bender did a good job directing. Brad Dourif wasn't as good as he was in 1&2 but still does good voicing Chucky. Justin Whalin not as good as Alex Vincent but does a pretty good job taking over the character. Perrey Reeves was good. They are better characters thaan anybody in 4&5. Travis Fine did well in his role. Dean Jacobson did a good job. Jermey Sylvers is no Alex Vincent but he did fine. Childs Play 3 is an underrated sequel a lot better than 4 & 5 & you will find out why I don't like them soon.
summary: Childs Play 3 review 8/10 why I like this sequel

reviewText: At the end of the first movie, Chucky is killed. At the beginning of the second movie, you see Chucky being rebuilt. At the end, he is killed again. At the beginning of the third movie, you of course, see him being built  again. Andy is now years older and has joined the military. Well, Chucky  has tracked him down again. He begins to do his killings again. From the  beginning to the middle, the movie was good, but the end was great. The end  was the best of the three movies. It takes place behind the scenes of an  amusement park, located just a few blocks from the military. The acting  could have been slightly better, but still good for this type of movie. I  have seen this movie many times and very much enjoy it.

reviewText: I was never a big fan of the series myself. (come on, a doll)  But I was willing to give this movie a chance. I seen it and I said, "I think I have just gotten 6 percent dumber." Whats also good about it, is that it signified the end of the movie so I could get back to doing more important stuff like writing other reviews about bad horror flicks. reviewText: Most reviewers seem not to have liked Childs Play 3 as much as as Childs Play 1 and 2, but I actually thought it was a pretty decent sequel. Especially considering that the writer of the movies had run out of idea's after Childs Play 2 but was pressured into making this (which was realeased only nine months later) straight away.Childs Play 3 takes place eight years after the ending of Childs Play 2. Theres the usual chucky-doll-being-brought-to-life-again scene during the opening credits and then we see that Andy is now 16 years old an enrolled in military school. Meanwhile, The Play Pall's Toy Company decide to start making a new batch of Good Guy's (and the prototype just happens to be Chucky). After a brutal murder (his favourite type), Chucky posts himself to Andy at the military school and it's not long before the body's start piling up as he continues he quest to get revenge on Andy.Im not sure why this movie was rated 18 as it is actually milder than the first two movies. Definatly should've just been a 15.Childs Play is quite scary and has a few moments that make you jump. Although the story line and death scenes are not as good as other Child's Play movies, this movie does succeed in being very suspencefull and has some good one-liners from chucky. Deffinatly worth watching if you are a fan of the series.

reviewText: The first sequel to Child's Play was decent, but this one actually left a lot to be desired. Jump ahead about ten years or so, so that Andy is now a teenager/young man at a boot camp, and Chucky finds his way to Andy in yet another attempt to possess the body. There's some funny bits in this film, but overall, this film was considerably more cheesy, even with the gory scene that results from Chucky replacing paintballs in the guns with real bullets. If you watched the first two, go ahead and watch this one, you may enjoy it.

reviewerName: Meesha "I'm A Lonely Angel Stuck On The Slow ...
reviewText: There was something that just didn't click with this film. Apart from the fact it has the scariest cover for a Childs Play movie so far. Brrrrrrr. It was slightly slower, and after a fantastic ending of Childs Play 2, it carried on with a fabulous way of bringing Chucky back (his blood gets into the new dolls), but then seemed to get stuck into a rut.There's a hint at romance between the new actor playing Andy, Justin Whalen (anyone else thinks he looks like the guy from Opposite of Sex?) and the tough girl, but it's never really followed through. Chucky manages to attack another kid this time, who's literally so into the dolls, he reminded me of the kid from Bad Santa.Screenwriter Don Mancini was actually pressured into writing the third, before the second was even released, and he says this is his least favourite, as he didn't have much time to get new ideas.Chucky is also less violent and creepy (apart from the cover), and there's no funny moments anymore involving him. There's only a great one-liner, and I'd get blacklisted from Amazon if I repeated it in my review. But you guys who've seen the film will know the one I mean. There is one inventive killing, rather than the standards, which is garotting someone - brought me straight back to my history class at high school, when I actually found out what that was. Bleurgh.The series is starting to fall flat & run out of steam, so I'm hoping that Bride & Seed Of Chucky pick it up, and give us more scares. This one carries on the story well, but not brilliantly, and might be one to be avoided.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Film Name: Child's Play 3Year Made: 1991Overview:  Young Andy Barclay is now a teenager and is enrolled in a military school.  Andy is told it's time for forget about dolls and the childish stories of his past, but can he forget for long?  Once again a toy company is determined to put the past behind and bring back the good guy doll.  In the words of Chucky, "You just can't keep a good guy down"  and hes back to claim a new soul!The Package:  2 StarsI love the cover with the face of Chucky on the front.  Inside though, there is no inlay and only the disc.  The disc pops out of the holder pretty easy and stays in place when put back in which is great.  The film is in widescreen but there is no closed caption on this one.  As far as extras, there is the trailer included which is great, however nothing is included beyond that.Spook Meter:  2 StarsSome light spooks, mixed with tons of great Chucky humor!  Their is not a whole of build up here in this film and Chucky gets on a roll pretty fast.  Not really scary, but some of his one liners are some of the best.Gore/Violence Meter:  2 StarsNot much blood at all, however some of the kills are pretty good. I would say the violence is pretty tame on this one but there are a few graphic scenes.  One scene a guy gets his throat slashed when he tries to give Chucky a haircut that is pretty graphic, other then that, the violence is pretty mild. Hey, you can't blame Chucky, he don't like anyone messing with his hair.Profanity Meter: 4 StrikesThere is a lot of profanity in this film.  Viewers beware!Sexual Meter: 1 StrikeThere are no in bed, make out scenes in this film at all.  No nudity what so ever.  There is only one single mild kissing scene.  Viewers concerned about sexual themes, have nothing to worry about watching this film.Final Thoughts:  Child's Play 3 was really great to watch when it came to Chucky!  He has tons of funny sayings in this film that will make you laugh a lot.  Chucky laughs a lot in this one also which always makes me bust out laughing too, what can I say, I love Chucky!  So why not 5 stars?I really enjoyed Child's Play 3, however Andy Barclay is not played by Alex Vincent in this one.  Since the character of Andy Barclay is in his teens in this film, Alex Vincent was not quite old enough in real life to fit this role.  Andy is now played by Justin Whalin and although he did a good job, I felt that Alex Vincent brought a very special vibe that is missed greatly.  Overall though, I loved Child's Play 3 and although not 5 stars, it still was a lot of fun to watch!Thank you for reading my review!
summary: You just can't keep a good guy down!

reviewText: The third entry in the popular killer doll series has a lot going against it, including some improbable actions by the characters and the sense of deja vu with the Chucky killings.  Chucky's been resurrected thanks to some of his blood dripping into thd doll making process, and he's on a killing rage again.  This time, though, he eschews going for a now 16 year old Andy Barclay, opting to try out the new little boy, Tyler, who attends the same military school Andy's been remanded to.  Justin Whalin takes over the role of Andy from young Alex Winter and although he's a capable actor, his character continues to do stupid things; you think he'd learn by now that people are not going to believe him about the killer Chucky doll.  There's not a whole lot of suspense in this one, because since we've already been through two movies with the demon doll, we know where this one's going to end too.  The climax takes place in an amusement park, and Chucky is offed again, although we know he's still got two more movies in him.  Tepid but should entertain those who have found themselves addicted to the Chucky series.

reviewText: THIS TIME, CHUCKY GETS YET ANOTHER NEW BODY. HE QUICKLY GOES AFTER ANDY BARCLEY AGAIN, WHO IS BY THE WAY, 16 YEARS OLD AND IS A STUDENT AT A MILITARY SCHOOL. HOWEVER, A YOUNG BLACK KID IS TOLD BY CHUCKY THE SECRET OF HIS TRUE IDENTITITY AND NOW HE'S THE TARGET. DEFINITELY NOT AS ENTERTAINING AS THE FIRST TWO MOVIES. ONE THING THEY SHOULD'VE NEVER DONE WAS SHOW ANDY AS A TEENAGER. THEY SHOULD'VE KEPT SHOWING HIM AS A KID. HAD THEY DONE THAT ONE THING, THIS SEQUEL WOULD'VE TURNED OUT A LOT BETTER. ONE THING THAT WAS GOOD ABOUT THIS MOVIE IS ITS FINALE, WHICH TAKES PLACE IN A CARNIVAL. MUCH OF THE STUFF THAT LEADS UP TO THE FINALE IS MEDIOCRE. JUSTIN WHALIN JUST RUINED THE DIRECTION OF THE ANDY BARCLEY CHARACTER. THANK GOD FOR BRAD DOURIF. WITHOUT HIM, THIS SEQUEL WOULD'VE BEEN MUCH MORE DIFFICULT TO WATCH. FOLLOWED BY BRIDE OF CHUCKY.

reviewText: 8 years after the events of the second film, Andy Barclay [Played now by Justin Whalin] is now at a military school when Chucky is again ressurrected in yet another new body, But this time, Andy's not the target, Chucky's instead after a young black boy and now it's up to Andy, The only one who knows all too well about Chucky, To put a stop to Chucky once and for all. Most of the reason this installment is so weak is the fact that they decided to make Andy's character into a teenager and they replaced the cool Alex Vincent with the wimpy Justin Whalin. There are a few funny moments here and there, But up until ''Seed Of Chucky'', This was the weakest of the Chucky movies. Brad Dourif tries his best to make Chucky at least be cool in this movie, Which he occasionally achieves, But it doesn't work as good against such a weak story. By the end of this movie, I could've cared less if Chucky finally killed Andy and if he killed the others in this movie. Stick with the first two films instead. Followed by Bride Of Chucky.

reviewText: Child's Play 2 actually managed to live up to the original film, so it was no surprise that a year later Universal rolled out another Chucky movie with Child's Play 3.  This time around, Andy (now played by Justin Whalin) is grown up and in military school, and of course Chucky is once again re-built, and soon tracks down Andy in hopes of revenge and transfering his soul.  The doll effects and gore are nice, but the acting is beyond lame, the killings aren't as imaginitive, and the story is beyond predictable.  Brad Dourif is on board again as the voice of Chucky, but even his menacing growl can't save this installment from mediocrity.  Followed seven years later with the more imaginitive Bride of Chucky, and the recently released (and beyond bad) Seed of Chucky.
summary: Pretty lame entry in the series
Title: N/A

reviewText: America's most popular serial killer doll is back, this time completely rebuild and remolded. How his soul survived the when the body was destroyed, and then exchanged completely, is a mystery to me but it's what they went with here. Chucked out less than a year from the previous installment, part three is plagued down with a rather poor script, dopey dialogue and weak characters.Chucky, still intent on claiming a human body, ventures out after Andy Barclay (who's files are conveniently in the Good Guy's owners office, where Chucky himself happened to be). Now why would the Good Guy owner order Chucky's body itself rebuilt, and then have it set in his office?? Doesn't make much sense either. But anyway, apparently the ornery old man has been keeping tabs on the Barclay kid whose tale threatened to turn his fortune into a pile of doll dust, and Chucky learns that Andy, now a teenager, has been shipped off to a military academy.Little plastic legs in tow, he somehow makes it over to the camp and sets his sights on the teen. Oh wait, that's right - he MAILS himself! All is going well, sort-of, until he runs into another kid, Tyler, who drops him down a flight of stairs. Realizing that now the rules have changed, he is after the nave African American child to play the old game of "hide the soul."Andy, paranoid as ever, suspects and then confirms the ol' Chuckster is back. But of course no one believes him. Chucky can't quite reach Andy to finish his old enemy off, Andy can't dig up adequate proof and has his own little wars going on with some of the other guys, as well as a possible love interest De Silva.Actually from far away it sounds sort of fun. Having Chucky in a military camp is a refreshing change of scenery; the potential for some ultimate massacreing was in the air.In some ways this was taken advantage of, while in other ways they could have done more.Justin Whalin (Andy) does a decent job but the personality is a bit too whiny and wimpy for sympathy. De Silva (played by Perrey Reeves) is a bit too stereotypically "tough" to be overly realistic. Chucky's new interest for a soul portal (Jeremy Sylvers) wasn't the best actor, and his scream is undeniably feminine. Travis Fine as Shelton was great though; I enjoyed all the scenes with him.Some of the kills were pretty humorous, the paintball scene winning hands down. Funny. The garbage man's demise disturbed me. Some of the other kills, such as with the barber, were a bit too hokey. But all through it Chucky was as animated as ever. They definitely make this doll look realistic, and his jokes were actually chuckle-inducing. By now he's growing a bit tiresome as the plastic comedian but he's still working. Unfortunitely the movie isn't.There was a bit more blood dabbled on this sequel and that works, and in a way it's darker than the other two. The directing of the film was alright but it didn't contain much style. Jack Bender tried to create some suspense; sometimes it worked and other times it didn't add up to too much.The finale takes place in a carnival placed conveniently near the academy. There are actually some semi-freaky shots going on there and I really got into that sort of setting for these scenes.Overall the plot has enough holes to resemble a crocheted blanket, Chucky is aging fast, none of the characters could be cared about, and nothing exciting really happened. Basically lackluster, although on the surface a decent enough idea.

reviewText: This was another childhood favorite! I remember that I got this for a Christmas present when I was little. It's been 6 years since Chucky was blown up, and now he's been brought back to life. He finds out that Andy Barclay has been placed in Kent Military School. Colonel Shelton gives everyone a hard time, especially Andy. Andy makes new friends like Tyler, De Silva, and Whitehurst. Tyler finds Chucky and Chucky figures on trying a new kid, instead of Andy. Andy knows that Chucky's back and he wants to stop Chucky from taking over Tyler's soul. A final showdown happens at a county fair, in the haunted house ride. If you love Chucky, you'll love CHILD'S PLAY 3!!!

reviewText: Child's Play 3 for me, is the most entertaining entry in the series. 8 years after being blown up, the Play Pals factory is back in business and accidently revives Chucky with some of his own blood. He then begins to track down Andy, who is now 16 and is more than able to kick the Chuckster's arse.However, he gets sent to Military School and goes through hell. He meets a naive friend named Tyler, who meets Chucky first and the stalking begins.The kills are pretty good in this movie, but since it's the final installment, it focuses most on Andy and Chucky's rivalry build up till the end, and their conflict over Tyler who is the new target. People say this is the worst of the series, but it's actually the most clever. The one liners from Chucky are priceless, better than the scripted junk he says in Bride and Seed. Plus the climax ending is one of the best I've ever seen. Andy does what he always wanted to do, and that's kill Chucky FOR GOOD with his own bare hands. Speaking of which, I believe Chucky died for good in 3. There was NO way he could of came back, mostly for 3 reasons.1. He was TORN TO SHREADS!!!!! How can he possibly be stitched together after all that. Watch his death in slow motion. His entire head was squashed and cut to itty bitty pieces. Plus he was bleeding like crazy. If his remains from 3 were accurate in Bride, then Tiffany would of tossed him into the garbage after so many failed attempts to revive the little you-know-what. Better get Voodoo for Dummies vol 2.2. I highly DOUBT that the cops would investigate a normal working amusment park fan to look for this "Chucky" Andy must be extremely certain that Chucky is dead, so why bother telling the cops it was him who caused the murders? When the amusement park closed, the clean up crew probably found his remaining pieces and tossed him in the trash, bye bye Charles.3. There's no amulet, never been mentioned by Chucky or by John(the black voodoo guy from the first) who TAUGHT Chucky about Damballa in the first place, so obviously Bride was made from stratch.To top it off, Andy defeated his nemesis in a awesome trilogy about a killer doll who WANTS TO TAKE POSSESSION OF A CHILD'S BODY. Not to screw old flames and make gender confused wimps and pshyco frizzy haired daughters. The Child's Play trilogy is best as it is, the rest is ignored.However, I will accept a Chucky v.s. Leprachaun someday, but without Tiffany, Glen, or Glenda's presence. Just both midgets going at it like Jason and Freddy.

reviewText: The Chucky doll lives on......again......he's back.......for the3Rd time....blah,blah,blah!.After the 1st to CP movies,it is tiresome and disapointing to watch this.It has the same BASIC idea:Chucky after andy's soul.The only twist:Chuckies blood has now infused into a new doll.But now,i'll get to the good and bads of the movie:GOODS:1.Good 'n'gory.2.A good dose of horror3.The Fair at the end is a rather good end setting,as the end in CP2 was a good setting._________________________BADS:1.Milatay Setting was a bad idea.2.Boring and predictable.3.Not as exiting due to lack of refurbishment to story.4.SF were way to terrible.5.Needs more "jolts"in the early scenes.EXAMPLE:Killings,Gory ones.!6.Boring till the last 30-40 mins.Easily,this film is the worst in the series.

reviewText: Okay, there are some genuinely funny moments in the film, but the acting and plot(even by this series standards) leaves much to be desired.First off, the Play Pals company is allegedly so scarred by the allegations surrounding their product, but the company HQ is miraculously open during all of this, and is never shut down despite the obvious catastrophe the allegations would create (investors withdrawing money and leases expiring)Secondly, the casting (Whalin is one of the lone exceptions to the rule) ...one can easily guess which characters are going to be the victims---deserving or not. For a military brat, Tyler is unbelievably naive about the real world and is way too trusting of a talking doll. Hello, it does not take a scholar to figure out the doll is only supposed to do what the box says it will.Still, because it does not sink ...like the final installment, I have to to give it the extra star. The film at least tried to explain what happened when our protagonist grew up---and could not escape the chilling memories of his childhood.

reviewText: Chucky, the murderous doll with a mind of its own, tracks teenage Andy to his military boarding school where he runs roughshod. If only this movie told us about the ending of Child's Play 2....It would have been inproved., amatuerishly directed sequel had as much strength as Chucky's vengeance.  This movie was just as good as Child's Play 2.  Music still sounds likethe ChUcKy Music we all heard!GREAT MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!SEE IT!RENT IT!BUY IT!

reviewText: Child's Play 3 is easily the worst installment of the Child's Play series.The first movie was awesome,the second was just as good,but this doesn't quite stack up to them.Now this added an extremely cool twist to  the series: Chucky in a military school. He could really kick a$$ there.He  does,but for some reason,just isn't as cool as in the first two.Here are  some problems CP 3 has: the story is extremely predictable,the direction is  a little weak,and compared to the other three CP films,it just doesn't  stack up.I still liked CP 3 very much.The death scenes are great and pretty  damn gory,the special F/X are great,the gore is pretty high so if your  looking for gore,you won't be  disappointed at all.Chucky also has some  awesome one-liners here.CP 3 is still worth buying and checking out.Rated  R for some pretty gruesome death scenes and lots of salty language.
summary: Very cool despite being the worst Chucky film

reviewText: Eight years after the events of Child's Play 2, though that the makers of the Good Guy dolls, can't seem to help but to try to keep the factory going after what went on with one of their dolls.  Just when Andy thinks that he can possibly get on with his life, Chucky eventually makes his way back to him in some way.  Upon seeing that Chucky had found out where he is, what he don't know is that he had found someone `new' to play with and try to transfer his soul into a human body, and tries everything he can to help put a stop to him for good.  That doesn't stop Chucky from unleashing some hell on the way and killing those who get in his way in any possible, though eventually this time it ends up that ends up being his downfall.  Overall I give Child's Play 3, 2.5 stars out of 5.
summary: Just when you thought that Good Guys were safe once again

reviewText: Those movie critics are really dumb for hating this movie.Oh,you say this movie is unwatchable,but you think the Bear is something worth watching.Forget what the movie critics tell you.Don't listen to what they say.See something that you want to see,not something someone else wants you to see.With that out of the way,this movie was the best out of all the Chucky movies.It even has some really funny parts in it too.The movie has alot of bloody death scenes(one being the garbage truck scene).This movie is really good from beginning to end.If you like scary movies,then you need to see this movie.It is great.Peace Out.

reviewText: One of filmdom's most notorious killers is back to wreak more mayhem as Chucky continues his quest to possess the body of a human child.Eight years after seemingly destroying the killer doll, Andy Barclay (Justin Whalin) turns 16 and is placed in a military school.Meanwhile, the greedy president of Play Pals Toy Company decides to resurrect the popular "Good Guys" doll line, confident that all the bad publicity is forgotten. As the assembly line recreates the first doll from a mass of melted plastic, the spirit of Chucky returns to renew his quest and seek revenge on Andy & once again it's up to Andy to stop the unrelenting killer in this fast-paced thriller.CHILD'S PLAY III takes me back to memory lane to when I was 19 years old and I Freshmen in college at Imperial Valley College in Imperial, CA which was when Universal released this horror flick back in the Fall of 1991 which was also when FREDDY'S DEAD was theatrically released by New Line Cinema.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Many have disregarded "Child's Play 3" as being complete and utter trash. This comment actually comes from many ardent Chucky fans who look at the film as being the weakest in the franchise. This may be true, but "Child's Play 3" is entertaining, horrific, smart, and daring as far as thrillers go. The producers did admit they were running out of ideas by the time the third installment was produced, but in all fairness I like "Child's Play 3". In this outing Chucky, again, comes back to life when the company that manufactured the "Good Guy Dolls" wants to bring back "The Chucky Doll" with hopes that the public has forgotten the terrifying elements associated with the toy. The young boy in the first two films, Andy, is now a teenager in a military school where Chucky tracks him down to invade his soul.Brad Dourif, who voices Chucky, gives another superb performance playing a crazed, psychotic killer. Who can ever forget that voice. Dourif's voice is creepy, horrifying, and unforgettable.Unfortunately, "Child's Play 3" only grossed a paltry $20,000,000 at the boxoffice making it the poorest money-making "Chucky" film. However, the franchise was resurrected in 1998 with "The Bride of Chucky" where audiences flocked to packed theatres signalling they still had an addiction to the Chucky films."Child's Play 3" is available as a stand alone DVD or in the great "Child's Play" box set that features all the Chucky films with the exception of the original "Child's Play" as that film is owned by a different studio.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Chucky the killer doll is back once again in CHILD'S PLAY 3! After being rebuilt by the Play Pals Toy Company, Chucky once again resumes his search for Andy Barclay, the boy Chucky wants to transfer his soul into. It turns out that Andy is now a teenager attending military school, and Chucky is going to show him what war is all about!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film may be the weakest of the series, but it's still great! Andy Barclay is all growed up now (well 16) and has been sent to Military school. He's still haunted by his past, namely his 'Good Guy' doll Chucky.Though Chucky can now swap bodies with someone new, this is a retread sequel. But none the less is good fun, mainly because of Chucky's mannerisms and one-liners.Taking place at a Military school and a ghost-train type fairground ride, this film has a gothic feel to it. Not a lot of gore but then that's not what this series is about, but Chucky himself takes quite a kicking!Kevin Yagher who usually oversees the puppet work, doesn't do it directly this time, and the film does suffer slightly because of this.I don't really understand the criticism of this film. Yes it's the weakest of the series but if you think of the 'Elm Street', 'Friday The 13th', 'Halloween' and 'Texas Chainsaw' series, they all have some absolute abysmal sequels in there somewhere, whereas this film isn't even bad.All-in-all a fun film, whether you're a Chucky fan or not.
Title: N/A
